critique: This document pertains to trade and movement of goods in New Orleans during a period of military governance. It seems to facilitate trade under the supervision of the military governor. There's no clear indication of ideological tilt, immigration policy, or expansion of executive power beyond the context of military necessity. Federalism isn't directly addressed, but the federal government is enabling the military governor's decisions. National security is a consideration, as trade is permitted to ports not blockaded by the US. Economic regulation is present in the form of permits and clearances. Social inclusion isn't directly relevant.
